items.title: HowTo access non control_type
COMError: An event was unable to invoke any of the subscribers
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Invoke hyperlink and then continue to next step in code

## Actual Behavior
Invokes hyperlink **but** then hangs until COM Error is raised:

`_ctypes.COMError: (-2147220992, None, (None, None, None, 0, None))`
which also translates to when catching Exception as e:
`(-2147220991, 'An event was unable to invoke any of the subscribers.', (None, None, None, 0, None))`

As of now I catch the exception and move on, however, as it hangs for approx. 20 secs this slows everything down dramatically. Therefore, a satisfying fix would simply be to raise the error faster?


## Steps to Reproduce the Problem
1. Use backend='uia'

```
(self.subwin[0]
                .children()[index]
                .children()[0]
                .children()[7]
                .children(title='BlaBla', control_type="Text")[0]
                .children(title="BlaBla", control_type="Hyperlink")[0]
                .invoke())
```



## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.8
  - Python version and bitness: 3.7.3
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10

items.title: drag_mouse_input code is likely to be partial/wrong
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
A correct drag&drop from a point A to a point B, with intermediate steps on the line [AB]

## Actual Behavior
It "flies" correctly from A to B, but the intermediate steps are inconsistent and do not simulate a human drag

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Do a simple : `app.drag_mouse_input(dst=(100, 100), src=(300, 300), absolute=False)`
  2. Set timings to slow() mode to have time to see the cursor moving, and see how strange the intermediate steps are located
  3. to understand, look at code around line 898 in base_wrapper, inside the for loop, there is no sense to this line of code:
`self.move_mouse_input((press_coords[0] + i, press_coords[1]), pressed=pressed, absolute=absolute)`

It can be expected an interpolation from src to dst to generate the famous 5 intermediate mouse positions, and as of today, the code just add one pixel towards the right direction

In the best case scenario it handles badly a horizontal drag from left to right, in any other case, the behaviour is not correct

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
`app.drag_mouse_input(dst=(100, 100), src=(300, 300), absolute=False)`

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.8 
  - Python version and bitness: 3.7 64bits
  - Platform and OS: Windows

items.body:
**This is not an issue - but a request**

I'm a novice in python, perhaps I was still able to use pywinauto and do a good set of automation in the Unified Service Desk of Dynamics 365.

Now that I struggle a lot to progress quickly to cover more scenarios, I was looking for the below:

- A good tutorial with examples on how to use pywinauto libraries including how to use the uia_control wrappers
- A utility similar to inpect.exe but generates the pywinauto code to the action that we do on the uia control
- The same utility to give the hierarchical path of the uia control. because using the print_control_identifiers output to navigate the controls is way too difficult in complex application like USD
-  How to switch between wpf controls and html components

@vasily-v-ryabov @airelil @enjoysmath

items.title: Unable to click/interact with QT App
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Click action performed by pywinauto.
## Actual Behavior
No click action happens, nor any interaction for that matter.
## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Substitute anki_Path with the path to [Anki](https://apps.ankiweb.net/) application
  2. Run code

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
The following are two different implementantions of the code, I've included them both since both of them return different objects when printing **anki**.
```
anki_App = Application(backend="uia").start(anki_Path)
anki = anki_App.window(title_re=r".* - Anki", class_name="AnkiQt").wait('Active', timeout=20, retry_interval=0.5)
anki['Import File'].click_input()
```
First one returns: <pywinauto.application.WindowSpecification object at 0x02E63820>

```
anki_App = Application(backend="uia").start(anki_Path)
anki_App.top_window().wait("Visible") #Wait for Anki's sync to server
anki = anki_App.window(title_re=r".* - Anki", class_name="AnkiQt")
anki['Import File'].click_input()
```
Second one returns: uiawrapper.UIAWrapper - 'User 1 - Anki', Dialog
## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.8
  - Python version and bitness: Python 3.8.2 64-bit
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10
[Control identifiers for reference](https://github.com/pywinauto/pywinauto/files/4513486/control_identifiers.txt)
Thank you for your time.

items.body:
## Expected Behavior

For the tests to run through automatically, on their own.  Or for the on-screen instructions to make sense.  The message box shown in the image below seems to indicate that right-clicking on the tray icon will progress you further into the tests. 

## Actual Behavior
It pauses at:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1606391/78454995-9fe0ea00-7650-11ea-850b-75356f7de66d.png)

If you follow the dialogs instructions, and hit OK, it repeats itself, going to control panel then opening the exact same dialog.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem
1. Same with either 64-bit or 32-bit Python.  But install Python 3.6.5 and make sure it's the first python that shows up with `where python`.
2. Install the required dependencies with `pip install -U -r dev-requirements.txt`
3. Run `nosetests --with-coverage --cover-html --cover-html-dir=Coverage_report pywinauto\unittests`

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version:
    Default branch of pywinauto/pywinauto github repository.
  - Python version and bitness:
    32-bit -or- 64-bit Python 3.6.5
  - Platform and OS:
    Windows 10, 64-bit

items.body:

items.title: An exit error PyQt5 app with import pywinauto 0.6.8
items.body:
## Expected Behavior

Properly exit:
Process finished with exit code 0

## Actual Behavior

Non-proper exit:
Process finishen with exit code -1073740771 (0xC000041D)

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Run simple PyQt5 app with button that connected to exit function
  2. Press exit button
  3. Get an error if pywinauto was imported

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem

    import sys
    from PyQt5.QtWidgets import *
    import pywinauto
    class MainWindow(QWidget):
        def __init__(self):
            super(__class__, self).__init__()
            self.exit = QPushButton(self)
            self.exit.clicked.connect(self.pressed_exit_button)
        def pressed_exit_button(self):
            app.quit()
    if __name__ == '__main__':
        app = QApplication(sys.argv)
        window = MainWindow()
        window.show()
        sys.exit(app.exec_())

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.8
  - Python version and bitness: 3.8.0.0 x64
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10

items.title: Click button with pywinauto implies crash of a simple widget QT 5.2 application
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Click on PushButton works

## Actual Behavior
The QT 5.2 application crashes

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. With QT 5.2.1 create a simple widget application with a button
  2. Run this application
  3. Click on the button with pywinauto (last version) (same behaviour => crash if use of invoke on the button on inspect.exe)

Important : I have tried at home with Windows 8 and it works but at the work on Windows 7/10 (There is not Windows 8)  I have a crash . Moreover at home to set a simple string to a TextBox with QT 5.2.1 I had to update the source code of QT https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-55546
 and after it works.

So I would have two ideas/questions please :

1) maybe it could be a problem of pywinauto requirements I mean on https://pywinauto.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html it is said the framework works with QT5 but with my first tests QT 5.9 seems more stable for pywinauto (indeed QTBUG-55546 spoken before is solved in QT 5.9) Is there a recommended release of QT5 for pywinauto ? Some help to make work pywinauto with QT 5.2? (for my target, a more complex QT 5.2 application on Win10, the print_control_identifiers method doesnt even return the different controls but the control appear in the inspect.exe)

2) There is apparently an OS problem but could it be the different releases of Automation dlls (https://docs.microsoft.com/fr-fr/dotnet/framework/ui-automation/ui-automation-overview) between Windows 8 (it works at home) and Windows 10 (it doesnt work at the work) I doubt about it but why not or something in my Windows 10, a setting for example that could block ?

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem

        app = Application(backend="uia").start('./debug/sans_titre1.exe')

        app.MainWindow.print_control_identifiers()

        app.MainWindow.Custom.PushButton.click()


## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: last version
  - Python version and bitness: 2.7.17 (I have tried with Python 3.X too)
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10

items.title: TreeItemWrapper object is not subscriptable
items.body:
I have recently had to redo automation for one of our apps as the app changed significantly after a recent software update. We don't develop or maintain the app, we just utilize it. 

I have had to try to get all of the descendants of a window looking specifically at the tree items. Doing this returns a list of TreeItemWrapper elements. Looking at the documentation, I can find two conflicting (and possibly unchecked) definitions of what a TreeItemWrapper actually is.

## Expected Behavior
According to documentation [here](https://readthedocs.org/projects/pywinauto-fork/downloads/pdf/uia/), it is supposed to inherit click_input().

>**class pywinauto.controls.uia_controls.TreeItemWrapper(elem)**
Bases: pywinauto.controls.uiawrapper.UIAWrapper
Wrap an UIA-compatible TreeItem control
In addition to the provided methods of the wrapper additional inherited methods can be especially
helpful: select(), extend(), collapse(), is_extended(), is_collapsed(), click_input(), rectangle() and
many others

## Actual Behavior
When dealing with the element, I am simply writing `element[index].click_input()` and the code breaks here. The exception thrown is:

> 'TreeItemWrapper' object is not subscriptable

The inclusion of click_input() is also not mentioned in the newer [documentation.](https://pywinauto.readthedocs.io/en/latest/code/pywinauto.controls.uia_controls.html#pywinauto.controls.uia_controls.TreeItemWrapper) is this a bug? or was this something that was removed on purpose? Is there a way to make this work so I can click on that tree item?

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Get a list of **tree item elements** via ` elements = app.descendants(control_type="TreeItem")`
  2. Pick a known index `elements[0].click_input()`
  3. Error is thrown.

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
```
def openFile(file_name):
     elements = dlg.window(title=App,class_name=appClass).descendants(control_type="TreeItem")
     items = None
     for element in elements:
         #checking if the filename exists within the descendants list
          if re.search(r".*"+re.escape(file_name)+r".*", str(element), re.IGNORECASE):
               items = element
          items[0].click_input() # Error is thrown here
```

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.8
  - Python version and bitness: Python 3.8  x64 bit
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10 PC

items.title: Revise Application.cpu_usage() for atspi backend

milestone.title: pywinauto 0.7.0
milestone.description: Linux "atspi" backend + some re-factoring in the core interface (breaks backward compatibility).

items.body:
The initial implementation of linux.Application.cpu_usage() provides general cpu usage as reported by `ps` linux utility. From `ps` man:
> %cpu - cpu utilization of the process in
> 	 "##.#" format.  Currently, it is
> 	 the CPU time used divided by the
> 	 time the process has been running
> 	 (cputime/realtime ratio), expressed
> 	 as a percentage.  It will not add
> 	 up to 100% unless you are lucky.

We might investigate for a better option to report CPU usage over the specified period.

I am trying out pywinauto (coming from another ui automation framework https://github.com/Roemer/FlaUI).

I am trying to automate a windows program that accepts some arguments (from the command line).
Does pywinauto support passing arguments when starting the process?
If answer is no, is there a reason or it?

Regards Fredrik

items.title: pywinauto to trace, app Identifiers are not found,
items.body:
## Problem Description
Unified Service Desk is a CRM software, which is a desktop application.  Though its a desktop application, it used the browser in the background to handle all the request/response.  
It's like an application, which us SKIN over the browser.
When it was USD 3.3 version, we used inspect.exe to spy the objects and use it in the pywinauto code to execute, the script was working well.  
Now the USD was upgraded to version 4.1, we find the script not working and many identifiers are missing... 

Hence seeking help, please advise how to proceed.... 

## Expected Behavior
Identify the AutomationId while using inspect.exe

## Actual Behavior
AutomationId is not coming

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem
Software used - **Unified Service Desk 4.1** 
Previous version **Unified Service Desk 3.3**
  1. Spy USD 3.3 using inspect.exe, we used to get the AutomationId
  2. Spy USD 4.1 using inspect.exe, we do not get the many identifiers
  3. USD 3.3 was using Internet Explorer in the background, USD 4.1 is using Chrome in the background

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem


## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.7
  - Python version and bitness: 3.7 64 bit
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10 64 bit

@vasily-v-ryabov @funkyHat

items.title: How to access buttons in ToolBarWindow32 control?
items.body:
I happened to have a software that the Icon Buttons in toolbar are with class "ToolBarWindow32", but I don't found corresponding controls in pywinauto for this class. Only toolbar is the closet one. How can I use toolbar to access buttons for ToolBarWindow32 control? The toolbar in the software is with some big icon and when mouse hove on it, it will become a raised button and could be pressed. 

I also tried different spy tools. 
ViewWizard could only access the whole toolbar (with highlight box out of it).
UIASpy could list the toolbar and its sub Buttons. For each button, there is corresponding property like text, button count etc. 

How can I access the single button in this "ToolBarWindow32" control?

items.title: control.capture_as_image got a low resolution image
items.body:
When I use capture_as_image to save the screen_shot for the controls, I only got a low resolution image.

The code is like:
image = control1.capture_as_image()
image.show()       # _it shows a captured image correctly, but the image is blurred and seems to be a low resolution image._
image.save(path,format="PNG")   # it saved sucessfully, but with the same resolution as image.show()

How can I capture an high resolution image with control.capture_as_image()? Or what's the wrong parameter I set for the function?   I want to do some OCR for the captured image, but even with my eyes, the quality is too low. This may cause the high error rate subsequently.

items.body:

```
    app = Application(backend="uia").start("setups/wampserver3.1.7_x64.exe")

    Wizard = app['Select Setup Language']

    Wizard.OK.click_input()
```

How can i click okay on the select setup language window.

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
`dashboard = app.window(title="Unified Service Desk for Microsoft Dynamics 365")`
below line fails:
```python
dashboard.child_window(auto_id="MainWorkArea", control_type="Pane").child_window(title="Custom Panel", auto_id="Custom Panel", control_type="TabItem").child_window(title="AboutPanel", auto_id="AboutPanel", control_type="Custom").child_window(title="About Tool Bar- Ayava", auto_id="About Tool Bar- Ayava", control_type="ToolBar").child_window(title="Close USD", auto_id="Close USD", control_type="Button").click_input()
```

## Specifications
All latest versions
  - Pywinauto version: Python 3.7 (64 bit)
  - Python version and bitness: pywinauto
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10

items.title: Potential typo bug in pywinauto top-level file.
items.body:
Line 91 in `pywinauto/__init__.py` we have this code which looks like a typo ("ElementNotFoundError = findwindows.ElementNotFoundError" is duplicated as is), wasn't it supposed to be WindowNotFoundError instead ?

```
    WindowAmbiguousError = findwindows.WindowAmbiguousError
    ElementNotFoundError = findwindows.ElementNotFoundError

    if UIA_support:
        ElementNotFoundError = findwindows.ElementNotFoundError
        ElementAmbiguousError = findwindows.ElementAmbiguousError
```

items.title: Add caching of intermediate WindowSpecification widgets.
items.body:
I often want to browse the GUI in a hierarchical manner, using intermediate parents (found by auto_id, index...) to reach the proper children.

The WindowSpecification stores these steps in the "criteria" lists, and performs a whole lookup of each control when wrapper_object access is triggered, which can be quite slow (I use automation_id much more than faster lookups like class_name).

Since one often wants to perform all kinds of operations on descendants of a control, how about adding some kind of `WindowSpecification .cache()` methods which looks up the currently targeted widget, and uses it directly as "parent" in find_elements() the next time the WindowSpecification is chained to new (sub)criteria?

( This might be slightly related to https://github.com/pywinauto/pywinauto/issues/570 )

items.title: Improper log() arguments in codebase
items.body:
Hello,

Several calls to `ActionLogger().log()` follow the "print" syntax (comma-separated elements to concatenate) and not the logging syntax (msg with placeholder and then its formatting arguments).

For example in remote_memory_block.py:

```            
ActionLogger().log('Error: Write failed: address = ', address)
last_error = win32api.GetLastError()
ActionLogger().log('Error: LastError = ', last_error, ': ',
         win32api.FormatMessage(last_error).rstrip())
```   

This code seems to be rarely hit, but it will raise a "TypeError: not all arguments converted during string formatting" if it is encountered. Otehr log() calls use str.format() to directly issue a single string.

PS: thanks for the awesome GUI test framework

items.title: ctypes.ArgumentError: argument 1: : expected LP_POINT instance instead of pointer to POINT
items.body:
Reported on StackOverflow:
https://stackoverflow.com/q/57304399/3648361

## Expected Behavior


## Actual Behavior
```python
ctypes.windll.user32.GetCursorPos(ctypes.byref(cursor))
ctypes.ArgumentError: argument 1: : expected LP_POINT instance instead of pointer to POINT
```

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Install pywinauto
  2. Install `pyautogui==0.9.47`
  3. Run the mentioned code

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
```python
slider = content_of_page.find_element_by_id("SystemSettings_Display_Brightness_Slider")
slider.click()
pyautogui.dragRel(args.value, 0, duration=1.0, button='left')
pyautogui.click()
```

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: unknown
  - Python version and bitness:  unknown
  - Platform and OS: Windows


We should think on how to eliminate such errors even if another library behaves incorrectly. Maybe do explicit type conversion for every Win32 API function call.

items.title: 0.6.7 SetForegroundWindow is missing from pywinauto.win32functions
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
SetForegroundWindow is present in pywinauto.win32functions

## Actual Behavior
In pywinauto version 0.6.7, SetForegroundWindow is missing from pywinauto.win32functions

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Install pywinauto 0.6.6
  2. from pywinauto.win32functions import SetForegroundWindow
  3. notice that no error is shown
  4. upgrade to pywinauto 0.6.7
  5. import the same thing (from pywinauto.win32functions import SetForegroundWindow)
  6. notice the error: SetForegroundWindow is not found in win32functions.py

## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem


## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.7
  - Python version and bitness: 3.7.3 64bit
  - Platform and OS: PC Windows 10
  - I am using latest version of Pycharm to install pywinauto packages

items.title: Implement AtspiImage
items.body: For the Linux platform we need to suppor AtspiImage as descibed: https://developer.gnome.org/libatspi/stable/libatspi-atspi-image.html#AtspiImage

items.title: Provide access to title/cuebanner for Edit control
items.body:
Edit controls are considered title-less by pywinauto, even though programs like inspect.exe show a title equal to the cue banner. If I want to find a specific edit control based on the cue banner, I have to use `control_type=Edit, predicate_func=lambda e: e.element.CurrentName == name`, because as far as I can tell this property is not surfaced directly by pywinauto at all.

I think either Edit controls should have titles, or they should explicitly expose the cue banner in some obvious way.

Wait('enabled', timeout=20) should wait for 20 seconds

"Next is the button on "AddPrinter" Dialog which will be activated after downloading a package. So I used the below line to wait for the "Next" button to be enabled.

app.AddPrinter.Next.Wait('enabled', timeout=20)

## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.6
  - Python version and bitness: Python 3.5.3, 64 bit
  - Platform and OS: Windows 10

items.title: is_visible returns True for some not existing elements
items.body:
## Short Example of Code to Demonstrate the Problem
```
from pywinauto.application import Application

app = Application(backend="uia").start('notepad.exe')


foo = [
	'Menu',
	'Menufgaf',
	'Menufgaf1543']

for item in foo:
	print(item)
	bar = app.window()[item].is_visible()
	print(bar)
```
## Result:
```
Menu
True
Menufgaf
True
Menufgaf1543
pywinauto.findbestmatch.MatchError: Could not find 'Menufgaf1543' in ....
```

## Question!
Notepad.exe has no element 'Menufgaf'. Why is_visible() function returns True?
## Specifications

  - Pywinauto version: 0.6.7
  - Python version and bitness: 3.7.3
  - Platform and OS: Win10

items.title: dialogs fail to implement __getitem__
items.body:
This is a tad puzzling and for now just an empirical observation (I haven't drilled into the code to find out why).

But basically I I have a an app, and I can open a dialog box in that app and on that dialog box is a Help button. I want to fetch me that button and observe:

`app.top_window()["Help"]`

works fine.

but that's rather uncool in a sense as the Help button is on the dialog on on the top window so trying to do it better:

`dialog = app.top_window()["DialogTitle"]`

is totally fine and returns me the dialog. Then:

`dialog["Help"]`

bombs with:

`AttributeError: The control does not have a __getitem__ method for item access (i.e. ctrl[key]) so maybe you have requested this in error?`

but:

`dialog.Help`

returns the button!

Inconsistent behaviour and traps me a bit. I can't use attributes as in my code I do't know it's called Help at that point, it's in a variable, and I can find the button from the top_window using the dictionary access method but that's not kosher (if there are any ambiguities, other windows open with help buttons, I'm in trouble) but form the dialog I cna't use the dictionary access method.

For now, my work around is to use the top_window().

all the ComboBoxes on my form flutter. It took me some serious drill down effort to nail this to:

`ComboBoxWrapper.texts`

which literally expands the combobox and collapses it again all in the name, it seems of finding three child controls that turn out to be:
```
uia_controls.ListViewWrapper - '', ListBox
uia_controls.StaticWrapper - '', Static
uia_controls.ButtonWrapper - 'Close', Button
```

But I'm looking for a panel in fact (Pane10), and I find it and it's all good and the software alas has no title or name on that control, and so forth, but in finding it I have to endure unwanted ComboBox flutter?

What is the work around here? I'm curious. I will explore it some more, but I really don't need all the ComboBox children to be checked when looking for a control unless I'm looking for one of those children. In short I kind of expect and guess this is a hope for, a setting through which I can say: Don't expand controls in the best match search, the one I want is visible thank you.

Indeed the whole search seems a tad inefficient as find_best_control_matches calls build_unique_dict on all the controls in a window (hundreds) to build a name map for finding. But seriously it can break out and bail the minute it finds a perfect match I would guess.

I'm hoping I can find a better way to get the control for this pane that is reliable and avoid using this best_match approach.

items.title: can you please add following enum_child_windows() function for findwindows.py
items.body:
i need a function to enumerate all child window for a specified window, so I create this new test base on your original enum_windows() test, can you please add this new function to pywinauto? thanks
```python
#=========================================================================
def enum_child_windows(parent_hwnd):
    """Return a list of handles of all the top level windows"""
    windows = []

    # The callback function that will be called for each HWND
    # all we do is append the wrapped handle
    def enum_window_proc(hwnd, lparam):
        """Called for each window - adds handles to a list"""
        windows.append(hwnd)
        return True

    # define the type of the child procedure
    enum_win_proc_t = ctypes.WINFUNCTYPE(
        ctypes.c_int, ctypes.c_long, ctypes.c_long)

    # 'construct' the callback with our function
    proc = enum_win_proc_t(enum_window_proc)

    # loop over all the children (callback called for each)
    win32functions.EnumChildWindows(parent_hwnd,proc,0)

    # return the collected wrapped windows
    return windows
```

items.title: EditWrapper.texts method duplicates the content
items.body:
```EditWrapper.texts``` effectively duplicates the contents by reading it as ```rich_text``` and after it
appending the same with looping through the lines. (refer 3f89207b). I would suggest removing the ```window_text``` from the returned list of the method. Also it doesn't look that ```texts``` method is used internally for controls matching so I wouldn't expect any regression on it.
